text: how do you go from puzzling over pure
mathematics to deciphering the genetic
code for Eric Lander the solution was as
twisted as a strand of DNA I did math
and high school I did math in college I
did mathematics for my PhD in graduate
school because I like math not because I
ever really thought deeply about whether
I wanted to be a mathematician as a
career in the beginning he found numbers
fun as captain of the math team at New
York Stuyvesant High School Eric Lander
would get to school early every morning
just to do an extra hour of math you
would think this sounds so boring but it
was great because it was a whole bunch
of kids and it was run by the students
and I thought math could be kind of fun
Eric's love for numbers led him to a new
level of achievement when he won the
Westinghouse Science Talent Search and a
$10,000 scholarship for proving a
theorem that hadn't been proven before
it was a paper he wrote on quasi perfect
numbers nothing made a bigger difference
in my life was the first time I realized
I can actually create a new piece of
knowledge EW it was a little piece of
knowledge it's so empowering Eric Lander
thrived in that quest for knowledge he
was valedictorian of his class at
Stuyvesant valedictorian of his class at
Princeton and a Rhodes Scholar at Oxford
but when he got out of school he needed
larger problems to solve one of his
first jobs as an economics professor at
Harvard Business School wasn't enough to
satisfy Landers passion for discovery
the genesis of genius may be wrapped in
Lander family DNA brothers Arthur and
Eric challenged each other growing up
and it was his brother a neurobiologist
who turned him on to the possibilities
of biology he had sent me a few papers
and somehow it
set me off on a convoluted journey of
learning a little bit about the brain
and then having learn about cells and
molecules and realizing how to get all
the way down to learning about genes
Landers said his mathematical mind
toward a new challenge unraveling the
DNA double helix that passion led to his
involvement in the human genome project
where he spent more than a decade
leading an international effort to map
the building blocks of humanity base
pair by base pair today's main story is
a story for the ages researchers from
the public and private sectors announced
today here's the quote our species can
now read its own genetic code the human
genome project delivered on its goal
having gotten the chance to serve in
this way I I'm just enormous ly grateful
Landers team at the Broad Institute of
MIT and Harvard uses the data from the
sequence genome to develop new
techniques in battling human disease
from diabetes to cancer
all of this could become as cumbersome
and complicated as the genome itself but
the lander has a gift for simplicity
that attracts admirers even in the
highest of places there's a guy for
example Eric Lander who's just
world-class mathematician has done
extraordinary work on genetics helped on
the Human Genome Project but what I love
about him is that he's he can explain
things in English which is one of the
reasons why President Obama asked Lander
to become an integral part of the
President's Council of Advisors on
science and technology
both in and out of the lab Lander works
to ensure a new generation of scientists
benefit from the continuing almost daily
discoveries about the fundamental
building blocks of life I was in high
school I hated biology and there was no
such thing as genomics whatever you're
studying today it's probably not the
exciting thing you're going to be
working on in the future mostly you're
learning so that you'll be prepared for
things as they get invented or even
better invent them yourself
